Award.AwardTitle: Unveiling the connection between star-formation and galaxy structure in the early Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
Christina Williams is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at The University of Arizona. Williams will study the properties and processes that affect star formation and influence the structure of galaxies. Results from her research will allow a better understanding of how galaxies form and change over time. Alongside this research, Williams will reestablish an astronomy course at a tribal community college, and she will develop a mentoring network for the community college students to enhance their access to higher education.

This project will explore the physical origin of the connection between star-formation activity and morphology in galaxies at high redshift. Empirically, suppressed star-formation activity in galaxies is correlated with high stellar mass density (compactness), but the nature of this connection is poorly understood. Williams will investigate this relationship between star formation and structure through three analyses. She will use deep spectroscopy in conjunction with high-resolution imaging to study the kinematic properties and ionization conditions (diagnostics of the energy input into the interstellar gas) in star-forming galaxies. This study will indicate if compact morphology in galaxies enhances feedback. She will also use imaging and spectroscopy from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to test theories about the mode of stellar mass buildup in the first galaxies to quench star formation. Finally, she will combine the JWST data with a molecular gas survey that will address the relationship between star formation efficiency and structure in galaxies. For the educational component of her work, Williams will revive an astronomy course at the Tohono O'odham Community College. She will also establish a mentoring network, which will encourage students to continue their education beyond community college.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When galaxies stop forming stars, it marks one of the most transformative events in the life cycle of a galaxy. Their shapes and colors transform from large blue disks hosting new star formation to concentrated bulges composed of old and red stars. For decades, we have known that the most massive galaxies likely undergo this transition early in cosmic time, but the causes remain poorly understood.

Christina Williams was awarded an NSF Astronomy & Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to study this longstanding problem of galaxy evolution. Williams used the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile to measure the amount of cold molecular gas, the fuel for star formation, in early massive galaxies that no longer form stars. She found that the molecular gas reservoirs had been efficiently used up or destroyed, and the molecular gas disappears relatively fast, within the last few hundred million years. This finding suggests that early galaxies do not become less efficient at turning this gas into stars as they end their growth phase, ruling out the idea that star formation stops because the gas is stabilized against collapse to form stars by the growth of the bulge. Instead, it suggests a simple picture where new gas is prevented from falling onto the galaxy to form new stars, once its dark matter halo grows massive enough to keep the gas hot.

With improvements to infrared detectors on ground-based telescopes, we now know that massive galaxies stopped forming stars when the Universe was surprisingly young, only 1.5 billion years old. This poses a problem because even the deepest galaxy surveys to date have not conclusively identified such galaxies during their star-forming phase. Using ALMA, Williams also discovered a previously unknown star forming galaxy that was so obscured by interstellar dust, its stars are invisible to our telescopes. This discovery suggests that a large fraction of massive galaxies in the first billion years of the universe are either too faint or too red to be easily found with current telescopes, and may represent the "missing link" in the evolution of massive galaxies. This discovery indicated that such hidden galaxies may even have dominated the cosmic star production in the first 1-2 billion years of the universe. Further, it provides evidence that massive galaxies can grow steadily at modest star-formation rate, in contrast to the common idea that the growth of massive galaxies is rapid with extreme star-formation rates, as expected from a major galaxy merger.

In the future, answering the outstanding questions about the growth and death of massive galaxies will require new sensitive infrared telescopes, such as the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). As part of this project, Williams developed an innovative framework that incorporates existing state-of-the-art observations of the early universe to predict what will be observed with JWST. This novel science analysis tool is called JAGUAR (the JAdes extraGalactic Ultradeep Artificial Realizations) and is publicly available, enabling the astronomical community to maximize the scientific return of future JWST data. This tool also enabled predictions of what we can measure about early galaxies using the first generation of JWST surveys. Of importance to the science goals of this program, JAGUAR predicts that JWST should cover large areas of the sky in order to study massive galaxy growth in the first billion years after the Big Bang.

Alongside this research program, Williams developed a new Science Technology Engineering and Math (STEM) mentorship program for students from the Tohono O'odham Nation, whom own the land that hosts Kitt Peak National Observatory. The program organizes field trips for high school students to meet with Native American STEM undergraduate majors at University of Arizona, including lunch and a planetarium show. These meetings facilitate discussions about opportunities in STEM, navigating the systemic barriers to higher education faced by many Native American students, and future career plans. Feedback from students indicate that these experiences helped them consider college in their future academic path. This program now continues after the completion of this fellowship, funded by the Astronomy Department at University of Arizona.
